I will try to give some maybe unconventional advice (like all advice, maybe take it with a grain of salt). I did my fair share of applying to online apps, going to career fairs, tech infosessions, etc. This is equivalent to casting the widest net possible and hoping some fish land in it. I do know of a lot of people who go this route, and it certainly works for them.

However, the most engaging and useful internships I got did not come from any of those places. Find a domain that you are really interested in, and do some work in it. I don't think "full-stack software engineer" or "ML engineer" counts as a domain. For example, rather than applying to every "ML engineer intern" position under the sun, focus on learning Spark MLLib and working with Scala, see what paradigms and abstractions are actually used to deploy machine learning models in industry with this stack, and find companies that use that stack (they are more of them, and they are often bigger companies than you may think).

The best domains are such that there are maybe 10 people in the world that can mentor you and really care about this domain. These 10 passionate people often find themselves looking for people to collaborate with, and they often find themselves in SF/bay area, and they often find themselves at meetups related to their domains of expertise. I don't mean big tech company infosessions (which from my experience are basically just big marketing events), I mean programming language, open-source project, etc. meetups. I remember going to meetup talks and at the end some speakers would literally say "we're hiring, come talk to me if you're interested". In my experience, once you find these people and show that you're serious, it becomes surprisingly easy to get an internship. There are many people passionate about specific technologies and use-cases, and they love working with similar people.
